Proof of Lemma 5. Let $Z$ be the set of market-clearing cutoffs. Then by symmetry, if ${\cal P}\;=\;$ $(P_{1},\cdot\cdot\cdot,P_{m})\in Z$ , then any permutation of $P$ is also in $Z$ . It follows that
and

$$
\operatorname*{inf}_{P\in Z}P_{1}=\operatorname*{inf}_{P\in Z}P_{2}=\cdot\cdot\cdot=\operatorname*{inf}_{P\in Z}P_{m}.
$$

Call these two common values $P_{+}$ and $P_{-}$ respectively. By Proposition 9, $(P_{+},\cdot\cdot\cdot,\,P_{+}),(P_{-},\cdot\cdot\cdot\,,P_{-})\ \in\ Z$ . These are the greatest and least elements of the complete lattice of market-clearing cutoffs. Therefore, it suffices to show that $P_{+}=P_{-}$ .

We show the result for $\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{poly},\kappa}$ , and the result follows similarly f $\mathrm{or}\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{mono},\kappa}$ . It suffices to show that $P_{+}=P_{-}$ . Assume for sake of contradiction that $P_{+}>P_{-}$ . (By definition, $P_{+}\ge P_{-}.$ .) By the definition of market clearing, the total measure of students matched is equal to $S$ under either $(P_{-},\cdot\cdot\cdot\,,P_{-})$ or $(P_{+},\cdots\,,P_{+})$ . Therefore,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{+}]\,d\eta(v)=S=\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{-}]\,d\eta(v).
$$
To give the desired contradiction, we show that

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{+}]\,d\eta(v)<\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{-}]\,d\eta(v).
$$

Clearly, $\operatorname*{Pr}[v\!+\!X^{(\kappa)}>P_{+}]\leq\operatorname*{Pr}[v\!+\!X^{(\kappa)}>P_{-}]$ . Therefore, it suffices to show that $\operatorname*{Pr}[v\!+\!X^{(\kappa)}>$ $P_{+}\!]\;<\;\mathrm{Pr}[v\,+\,X^{(\kappa)}\;>\;P_{-}]$ on a set $I$ of positive $\eta$ -measure. We show this is the case for $I=(P_{-}-X_{+},P_{-}-X_{-})$ .
We first show that the inequality is satisfied on $I$ . Note that for $v\,\in\,I$ , we have that $P_{-}-v\in$ $(X_{-},X_{+})$ . Therefore,

$$
\mathrm{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{-}]-\mathrm{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P_{+}]=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\mathrm{Pr}[\kappa=k]\left(F_{X}^{k}(P_{+}-v)-F_{X}^{k}(P_{-}-v)\right)>0
$$

where the last inequality follows from observing that by $P_{+}\,-\,v\,>\,P_{-}\,-\,v$ by assumption and applying Proposition 7, which says that $F_{X}^{k}$ is strictly increasing on $(X_{-},X_{+})$ .
It remains to show that the interval $I$ has positive $\eta$ -measure. We begin by showing that $P_{-}>$ $V_{-}+X_{-}$ . This is true because for $P\leq V_{-}+X_{-}$ ,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X^{(\kappa)}>P]\,d\eta(v)\geq\int_{\mathbb{R}}\operatorname*{Pr}[v+X>V_{-}+X_{-}]\,d\eta(v)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}1\,d\eta(v)=1,
$$

contradicting the assumption that $S<1$ . Similarly, $P_{-}<V_{+}+X_{+}$ . It follows that $P_{-}-X_{+}<V_{+}$ and $P_{-}-X_{-}>V_{-}$ . Therefore, the interval $I=(P_{-}-X_{+},P_{-}-X_{-})$ intersects $(V_{-},V_{+})$ . So Proposition 8 implies that it has positive measure. 口

NeurIPS Paper Checklist
1. Claims
Question: Do the main claims made in the abstract and introduction accurately reflect the paper’s contributions and scope?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: We clearly specify the claims of our paper: a model of algorithmic monoculture in a matching markets context, and corresponding theoretical results.
2. Limitations
Question: Does the paper discuss the limitations of the work performed by the authors?
Answer: [Yes]

Justification: We note that our results hold in a theoretical setup that leverages symmetry; accordingly, we provide computational experiments in more general settings. We also note in the Broader Impacts section that we focus on quantitative measures of welfare, and not rights- or claims-based approaches.
3. Theory Assumptions and Proofs
Question: For each theoretical result, does the paper provide the full set of assumptions and a complete (and correct) proof?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: We provide complete statements of our results (and assumptions), and provide complete proofs in the appendix.
4. Experimental Result Reproducibility

Question: Does the paper fully disclose all the information needed to reproduce the main experimental results of the paper to the extent that it affects the main claims and/or conclusions of the paper (regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not)?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: Yes, we describe our experimental results in detail and provide full code to reproduce the figures and results.
5. Open access to data and code
Question: Does the paper provide open access to the data and code, with sufficient instructions to faithfully reproduce the main experimental results, as described in supplemental material?
Answer: [Yes]

Justification: We provide a link to an anonymized repository in the main text: https://anonymous.4open.science/r/monoculture-2076/README.md (which we would replace with a non-anonymized version in a camera-ready version)
6. Experimental Setting/Details
Question: Does the paper specify all the training and test details (e.g., data splits, hyperparameters, how they were chosen, type of optimizer, etc.) necessary to understand the results?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: We specify our (basic) training and test details. We use the default scikit logistic regression model.
7. Experiment Statistical Significance
Question: Does the paper report error bars suitably and correctly defined or other appropriate information about the statistical significance of the experiments?
Answer: [NA]
Justification: We do not make claims about statistical significance.
8. Experiments Compute Resources
Question: For each experiment, does the paper provide sufficient information on the computer resources (type of compute workers, memory, time of execution) needed to reproduce the experiments?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: We note that all of our experiments can be performed using a standard laptop in at most a few hours (i.e., our experiments are not compute intensive).
9. Code Of Ethics
Question: Does the research conducted in the paper conform, in every respect, with the NeurIPS Code of Ethics https://neurips.cc/public/EthicsGuidelines?
Answer: [Yes]
Justification: We have reviewed the Code of Ethics and verified that our research conforms.
10. Broader Impacts
Question: Does the paper discuss both potential positive societal impacts and negative societal impacts of the work performed?

Justification: Yes, we include a discussion of broader impacts in the main text.
11. Safeguards
